title: Talk - Leak of password-protected room name via already existent resource addition

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
CVSS
----

Medium 4.3 [CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N](https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N)

Description
-----------

Affected: Talk / Spreed 6.0.3

The name of shared but password-protected rooms leaks to low-privileged authenticated users. 

An attacker does not need to guess room IDs, but can simply iterate over IDs to gather all names of all affected rooms.

POC
---

Setup:

- Add a password-protected room: Talk -> New conversation -> enter a name -> Share link -> set password
- Add a project: Projects -> Add a project -> select a file

Attack with a low-privileged user: 

- Build the following request (eg by going to Projects -> Add project -> select a file in a project the user has access to):

        POST /nextcloud/nextcloud/ocs/v2.php/collaboration/resources/collections/21?format=json HTTP/1.1
        Host: 192.168.0.104
        User-Agent: [...]
        Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*
        Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
        Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
        Content-Type: application/json;charset=utf-8
        requesttoken: [...]
        Content-Length: 43
        Connection: close
        Cookie: [...]

        {"resourceType":"file","resourceId":"1619"}

`16` is the ID of the password-protected room that the user does not have access to. `1626` is the ID of a file that was shared under the "projects" tab in that room. It is required that the file is already shared, but IDs are iterative and can easily be bruteforced.

The response will contain the room name & ID and the name of the shared file:

    HTTP/1.1 200 OK
    [...]

    {"ocs":{"meta":{"status":"ok","statuscode":200,"message":"OK"},"data":{"id":21,"name":"privateprivateprivate","resources":[{"type":"file","id":"1619","name":"aaaa.txt","path":"files\/aaaa.txt","link":"http:\/\/192.168.0.104\/nextcloud\/nextcloud\/index.php\/f\/1619","mimetype":"text\/plain","preview-available":true},{"type":"room","id":"w3die6ou","name":"privateprivateprivate","call-type":"public","iconUrl":"http:\/\/192.168.0.104\/nextcloud\/nextcloud\/apps\/spreed\/img\/app-dark.svg","link":"http:\/\/192.168.0.104\/nextcloud\/nextcloud\/index.php\/call\/w3die6ou"}]}}}

## Impact

leak of all password-protected room names to low-privileged attacker

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.

I'm having trouble reproducing this reliably (I'm probably overlooking some prerequisite).

But this seems to be a systemic issue across the projects component. I have identified at least two other ways in which *all* private and/or password-protected room names leak to a low-privileged user and which can be reproduced reliably. 

Without having looked at the source in-depth, how conversation projects work seems to be roughly as following:

- when a new project is added to a conversation, a new `collections` resource is created and given the name of the room
- if anything that is already accessible with lower permissions is linked to this collection, the collection is assigned those permissions

Thus, the room name leaks. Two examples:

Talk - Leak of private room name to linked public rooms
=================================

CVSS
----

Medium 5.3 [CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N](https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N)

POC
---

Setup:

- Add a public room: Talk -> New conversation -> enter a name, select public
- Add a private room: Talk -> New conversation -> enter a name. No need to share the room, though this will also work with a shared, password-protected room.
- Add a project to the private room: Projects -> Add a project -> Link to a conversation -> select a public conversation

Attack:

- open the public room and go to projects. The name of the private room will be displayed in the web interface

Talk - Leak of private room name if public resource is linked
=================================

CVSS
----

Medium 4.3 [CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N](https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N)

POC
---

Setup:

- Add a public file / a file a lower-privileged user can access
- Add a private room: Talk -> New conversation -> enter a name. No need to share the room, though this will also work with a shared, password-protected room.
- Add a project to the private room: Projects -> Add a project -> Link to a file -> select the public file

Attack:

- perform the following request with a lower-privileged user without access to the room:

        GET /nextcloud/nextcloud/ocs/v2.php/collaboration/resources/collections/64?format=json HTTP/1.1
        Host: 192.168.0.104
        User-Agent: [./..]
        Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*
        Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
        Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
        requesttoken: [...]
        Connection: close
        Cookie: [...]

Where `64` is the ID of the collection. Any collection that belongs to a private room, but which links to a public file can be leaked here. The response will contain the name of the private room.

This means that a low-privileged attacker can easily iterate over all IDs and gather all room names of all private and/or password-protected rooms that link to any file the attacker has read access to.
Thanks for your report, I will look into it.
@nickvergessen I don't have the time to check this in-depth right now, but I'll look into it on the weekend.

Hi @nickvergessen ,

I'm not sure if this fixes the root of the problem. I can still reproduce the POCs (even after running `truncate table oc_collres_accesscache;`)

Another example where the room name leaks:

- Create a file with user A (admin) & share with user B (attacker)
- Share the file with a private room that user B cannot access (Details -> Sharing -> Add a project -> Link to a conversation)
- Visit the following URL with user B:

        GET /nextcloud/nextcloud/ocs/v2.php/collaboration/resources/file/2565?format=json HTTP/1.1
        Host: 192.168.0.104

        {"ocs":{"meta":{"status":"ok","statuscode":200,"message":"OK"},"data":[{"id":224,"name":"secretconversation title","resources":

Best,
Foobar7

Ah, I also just noticed that the final fix we applied is a bit different then the diff I posted above:
https://github.com/nextcloud/spreed/commit/e6070d272a85ab4b2cff258718e593d12f489025#diff-7fb7b53dfe69f1c9d42252ccab43fbb9

Thanks a lot for your report again. This has been resolved in our latest maintenance releases and we're working on the advisories at the moment.

Please let us know how you'd like to be credited in our official advisory. We require the following information:

- Name / Pseudonym
- Email address (optional)
- Website (optional)
- Company (optional)

Hi @nickvergessen,

> The room name is only leaked as resource collection name, when you go to the room and create the project there by linking it to the file. This is not really preventable.

> Also our long term vision is anyway that a project with an item you have access to will grant you the same permissions for all other items in this project.

> For now I think this is okay, because at least you can not iterate over all projects anymore, to gather a list of all public shared talk conversations.

I'm not so sure about this. I don't think a user sharing a public file to a private discussion would expect that this will leak the private discussion title to all users that have access to the file. 

I could think of two potential solutions here:

- (at least if it's a private conversation) ask the user to name the project themselves and make it clear that this name may be shared with anyone who has access to any resource in the project.
- only show projects to a user if the user has access to all elements in the project

(Silently) giving a user access to all items in a project once they have access to one item doesn't seem ideal. If you plan on making an explicit permission model for projects, that could be a different thing, but I'm not sure it would necessarily solve this problem. 

Best,
Foobar7

PS: You can credit me as Tim Coen (https://security-consulting.icu/)
PPS: Thanks for the bounty and the swag! I noticed that I haven't actually received the previous swag for #428010 though. Do you know if that went out already?

Right, that makes a bit sense and we opted for solution 2:
https://github.com/nextcloud/server/pull/16820

We used non alerting title and description on the pull request, so this can go into 17beta3 which is due to tomorrow, although the next maintenance release for 16 is still ~2-3 weeks away.
Regarding swag, I heard we are currently out of tshirts. But our conference is in september and I guess we will get a new set printed for that anyway and you should then receive it.

> (Silently) giving a user access to all items in a project once they have access to one item doesn't seem ideal. If you plan on making an explicit permission model for projects, that could be a different thing, 

well that is exactly the plan. But that is (as said) a long vision goal, so fo rnow we can make it a bit more strict.
